title: What is Infertility?
subtitle: Understanding your diagnosis
description: If you've been trying to conceive for 12 months without success (or 6 months if you're over 35), you may be experiencing infertility. This affects about 1 in 6 couples in Canada. Remember, infertility is a medical condition, not a personal failure. Many treatment options are available to help you build your family.
keyPoints: Affects both men and women, or both partners
Sometimes no cause is found (unexplained infertility)
Age, lifestyle, and medical conditions can all play a role
Early diagnosis improves treatment success

title: Common Causes of Infertility
subtitle: Why conception may be challenging
description: Understanding the cause of infertility helps determine the best treatment path. Your fertility specialist will perform tests to identify any issues. Remember, many causes are treatable, and even 'unexplained' infertility can often be overcome with the right approach.
keyPoints: Female factors: Problems with ovulation, blocked fallopian tubes, endometriosis, or egg quality
Male factors: Low sperm count, poor sperm movement, or sperm shape issues
Age-related: Egg quality and quantity naturally decline with age
Lifestyle factors: Weight, smoking, alcohol, and stress can impact fertility

title: How is Infertility Treated?
subtitle: Treatment approaches and options
description: Infertility treatment depends on the cause, your age, how long you've been infertile, and personal preferences. Modern medicine offers many effective treatments, from simple interventions to advanced reproductive technologies. Your fertility specialist will work with you to find the best approach for your situation.
keyPoints: Lifestyle modifications: Weight management, stress reduction, and avoiding tobacco and excessive alcohol can improve fertility
Medications: Fertility drugs like Clomid or Letrozole stimulate ovulation; hormones can improve sperm production
Intrauterine Insemination (IUI): Placing specially prepared sperm directly into the uterus during ovulation
In Vitro Fertilization (IVF): Combining eggs and sperm in a laboratory, then transferring embryos to the uterus
Intracytoplasmic Sperm Injection (ICSI): Injecting a single sperm directly into an egg during IVF
Third-party reproduction: Using donor eggs, sperm, or embryos, or working with a gestational carrier
Surgery: Correcting anatomical problems like blocked fallopian tubes, endometriosis, or varicoceles

title: What is Fertility Preservation?
subtitle: Protecting future fertility
description: Fertility preservation allows you to save eggs, sperm, or embryos for future use. This gives you more control over your reproductive timeline and can protect fertility before medical treatments that might affect it.
keyPoints: Egg freezing: Preserving unfertilized eggs for later use
Sperm freezing: Simple process with excellent success rates
Embryo freezing: Freezing fertilized embryos for future pregnancies
Medical reasons: Before cancer treatment, surgery, or gender transition
Personal choice: Delaying parenthood for career, education, or finding the right partner

title: Emotional Support & Resources
subtitle: You're not alone
description: Dealing with infertility can be emotionally challenging. It's normal to feel a range of emotions including sadness, anger, and anxiety. Support is available to help you through this journey.
keyPoints: Counseling: Many clinics offer fertility counseling services
Support groups: Connect with others who understand your experience
Online communities: Find support and information 24/7
Mind-body programs: Yoga, meditation, and acupuncture may help
Communication: Keep talking with your partner and support network

title: Financial Considerations
subtitle: Understanding costs and coverage
description: Fertility treatments can be expensive, but there are various funding options available. Some provinces offer coverage, and many employers provide fertility benefits. Planning ahead can help reduce financial stress.
keyPoints: Provincial coverage: Ontario, Quebec, and some other provinces offer partial IVF funding
Insurance: Check your extended health benefits for fertility coverage
Tax credits: Medical expenses including fertility treatments may be tax deductible
Payment plans: Many clinics offer financing options
Grants: Some organizations offer fertility treatment grants
